topic.body:
Here's an example of a new software recommendation:  
  
***  
  
Tor Browser Bundle 6.0.2 for Windows:
Intro:
Tor prevents people from learning your location or browsing habits.
Tor is for web browsers, instant messaging clients, and more.
Tor is free and open source for Windows, Mac, Linux/Unix, and Android
  
***  
  
And here is an example response:
***

***  
  
Users can verify MD5 and SHA256 sums and discuss the software in the thread. Please don't discuss the software in the top post.

topic.title: Zeronet Important Software Repository
topic.body:
This forum is discuss ZeroISR, a P2P decentralised software repository hosted on ZeroNet which hosts software which has been identified as critical by the privacy community.  
***    
Here we discuss possible additions to the repo and verify md5 and sha256 sums. This is an open community, so feel free to give us any recommendations you may have.

topic.title: [Desktop Software] Veracrypt 1.17 Windows
topic.body:
Veracrypt is a disk encryption program intended to be a successor to TrueCrypt.
VeraCrypt adds enhanced security to the algorithms used for system and partitions encryption making it immune to new developments in brute-force attacks.
VeraCrypt also solves many vulnerabilities and security issues found in TrueCrypt.

topic.title: [Desktop Software]  gpg4usb 0.3.3 for windows and linux (32 & 64 bit)
topic.body: gpg4usb is a very easy to use and small portable editor to encrypt and decrypt any text-message or -file you want.

topic.title: [Desktop Software] Bleachbit 1.12 Windows Portable
topic.body: BleachBit quickly frees disk space and tirelessly guards your privacy. Free cache, delete cookies, clear Internet history, shred temporary files, delete logs, and discard junk you didn't know was there. Designed for Linux and Windows systems, it wipes clean a thousand applications including Firefox, Internet Explorer, Adobe Flash, Google Chrome, Opera, Safari,and more. Beyond simply deleting files, BleachBit includes advanced features such as shredding files to prevent recovery, wiping free disk space to hide traces of files deleted by other applications, and vacuuming Firefox to make it faster. Better than free, BleachBit is open source.

topic.title: Planned Software:
topic.body:
The following is a list of software we plan on adding. As software gets verified (md5 & sha256 gets posted by 3+ people per version), it will be crossed out from this list. Feel free to throw in any suggestions.
***
# Desktop Software:
Tor Browser Bundle
GPG4USB
VeraCrypt
Bleachbit
Eraser
BitMessage
RetroShare
VirtualBox
Putty
VLC Media Player
ZeroNet
Pidgin and OTR
Ricochet.im
Jitsi.org
WinSCP
~~Tixati~~
Keepass
HashTab
## Need recommendations
None right now

***
# Android software:
F-Droid
Moboclean
Android IMSI Catcher Detector
Snoopsnitch
Paralell Spaces
~~ChatSecure~~
Conversations.im
Orbot
Orfox
AFWall+
Signal (Moxie Marlinspikes software)
CSipSimple

topic.title: [Desktop Software] KeePass 1.31 Portable for Windows
topic.body: KeePass is a free open source password manager, which helps you to manage your passwords in a secure way. You can put all your passwords in one database, which is locked with one master key or a key file. So you only have to remember one single master password or select the key file to unlock the whole database. The databases are encrypted using the best and most secure encryption algorithms currently known (AES and Twofish).

topic.title: Personal bios for the about us page
topic.body:
Hey guys. I'm gunna add some info about the top contributors to the about us page. Each of us will get maybe 2-5 sentences about ourselves, a role, and a 150x150px little avatar. What do you guys think about that? I figured it could be fun. I'm willing to change your description for you pretty much whenever you want, so don't be shy.  
Here's mine so far:
***
zeroexef -- the brawn
I do most of the heaving lifting around web design and editing. In my spare time I enjoy staring at text editors wondering why I can't get things to work. Someday Dreamweaver will put me out of a job.  
My icon: http://i.imgur.com/f4MRzk3.jpg

1_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
Windows:  torbrowser-install-6.0.2_en-US.exe (Downloaded July 26, 2016, 11:09 PM EST)
MD5: d4b74112374b75b38a8174b1d37086fe
SHA256: 3a2e05304345936fd713b638612088fa0914102389c15c7bf7aa1d74803e5db8
I think sha-256 and md-5 is a good choice. I'm no expert either, but I think it's a good standard. I'll edit the first posts

4_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf.body: Redesigned the site a bunch today. SHA256 and MD5 hashes are now on the main page.

> [testset](#comment_7_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp)
You're absolutely right. Good point. I'll move my linux hashes to a new thread.
Awesome! I personally hate scripting in bash. The if statements are real funky. I'm glad you're willing to go there haha

Good point. I hadn't thought of that. I suppose that the safest way to do all this would be to completely automate the site then throw away the key, but that comes with some obvious problems as well. As it stands I am currently keeping the key on an encrypted drive using Veracrypt's Serpent(Twofish(AES)) and a 25+ character password. As far as I can tell this is the best I can do. Any further recommendations?

The simple answer is I don't know. I don't think there's currently a way to do that, but I could always spend a few hours at some point seeing if I'm able to.  
It would be really helpful if somebody else with programming experience could look into making a script to do the auto checking. I'm thinking maybe a cron job that checks through the JSON files of ISRtalk and writes to a json file in zeroISR?  Gahh but that means I have to change the was zeroISR is made.  
Long story short, I'm not sure. Totally open to suggestions.
***
As for the shared key, I don't know how I feel about that. On one hand if we distributed and a single admin decided they where mad, they could destroy the entire site. On the other, if I am the only one able to access it, I could do the same thing (Not that I would of course, but I understand that you're all putting your trust in a complete stranger). Also, and far more likely, at some point I'm bound to get bored/busy with something else and stop working on this project. What do you all do then? I guess you could clone the site, but then the issue of getting people to move arises.  
Again, not sure. What do you all think?

Alright guys so Tox is a great software. I think it'd be good for everybody to hop in there. I made a thread for sharing Tox IDs, so hop in here and do the thing:  
http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CmNF5L1murN3UMb4fZMuWJtpq689JRhx/?Topic:14_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf/Tox+Chat+info+Post+your+tox+ID+in+here+so+that+we+can+all+connect+and+so+forth
***
> [testingzeronet12](#comment_19_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN): I'm not sure how Bitcoin cryptography works but would there be a way for multiple private crypto keys to write to document/website on zeronet, in the same way that a PGP message can be decrypted by multiple recipients if their public key was included in the initial encryption of the message?
> That way, multiple people can write to a zeronet document whilst having different keys. And it would be possible for the content.json to log exactly which private key made the last change.
> Maybe i'm 100% wrong on this.

That's over my head. Maybe? We might want to ask nofish about this directly.

Done. Let me know what you guys think.

> [testset](#comment_24_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp): Nice, but it would be even better if it were in a separated 'Description' drop down.Expecting people looking for description to click on the 'Download' drop down is quite strange.

I'll be honest, I hadn't even looked at what that said since I typed it. You're totally right. I'll fix it today.

2_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body:
I've said this before, but I can't find where so I guess here it goes.  
***
The primary aim of ISR is that everyone everywhere will always be able to access important software for their day to day life. This means that if the videolan website dies forever, or for some reason is compromised (think hackers or censorship), there will always be at least one verified genuine installer for VLC on ISR.  
The secondary reason is more due to the hacker/censorship/NSA sort of thing. We hope (yes, just hope) that the software we all know and love is not compromised at the moment. We can support this hope by the fact the many people across the world are using the same file as us. The reason this makes us feel better is that if, say, the NSA built a backdoor into bitmessage, they likely wouldn't do that for servers outside the US. Instead, they would more likely just redirect US website visitors to their own page, complete with compromised download.  
This is why the file hashing is important. It tells us that we aren't being sent a fake file (or at least everyone is, but we hope that's less likely).  For all intents and purposes, going to the official site to download might still be a good idea if you are able. Then take that link and cross check the hash against our table.   
***  
As for the target audience,  I'd say most people on zeronet. That is to say that people who have tech-backgrounds or maybe some concept of cybersecurity? Of course by no means do you need that to use our service, but much of our software centers around that.
***
So to summarize, ISR is here to make sure everybody is able to get their hands on untampered important software.

> [testset](#comment_26_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp): I like this part. How about stating it on the Zite in a separate first paragraph formulated as:"Our primary aim is to make important software accessible to everyone everywhere."?
Agreed.
> This is part is a bit confusing. For example, "the website dies forever" is quite an extreme case. So I'm not sure it is a good idea to use that for illustrating why our collection is useful. I think we should use more everyday situations here as government censorship and MitM/DDoS attacks. Also I'm not sure  VLC is the best example to be used in the illustration. I love VLC, but I'm not sure that is among the most endangered important software.  

Yeah' it's extreme. It's totally extreme. It also happened to TrueCrypt and limewire. "Ah" you say, "but those both allowed and possibly encouraged illegal activity". Well right you are. Isn't it a shame there aren't any other examples? Examples like Flappy Bird? Software disappears or changes all the time without notice. MySQL was used everywhere, I mean EVERYWHERE before Oracle bought Sun Microsystems. Christ, now you can hardly get people to agree to talk about it.  
So yeah, VLC is hardly a security issue, and I also doubt it will die forever, but stranger things have happened. Perhaps you're right though. There's no reason for us to host it if we don't think it'll disappear. ***Can I get anybody else's thoughts on this?***  
> The secondary reason also rises several questions: 
> 
> Isn't "supporting hope", "makes us feel better", etc. are misleading terms? Mallory and NSA want people "to feel secure". We should want them "to be more secure". See Bruce Schneier's The security mirage TED talk.  
**Haha yeah. No idea how to solve this one. It's a biggie too.**
> Are we more secure yet? (Especially looking us from out side. Can we give any guarantee that we are not 'group Mallory' trying to make people trust and use our software?)
> Can we become more secure than (or at least as secure as) the official source? If yes, how?  
Perhaps. That's probably the best answer I can give you. If we were able to talk to the devs of our software we could get encrypted and signed copies sent to us directly. This isn't super realistic, but it'll probably be doable for at least _some_ of the software. Anybody have any other ideas?

3_14J8mC3K7k5Ygx22uu9LUzGWnBoDAQdyDo.body:

We just need icons. fsf will be easy, but privacytools.io and prism-break don't seem to have anything usable. Does anybody have any experience with design? I'm thinking a 16x16px icon? Maybe 32x32px scaled down? I dunno, but we'll need something.
Works for me. Uni is starting up so I'm busy this weekend, but I'll do this at some point.

4_17VwZEfWSUWb5RHkK9m1odnDdBfvjTL6Cp.body: This is an awesome idea. I'm totally on board with this. This'll probably end up being completely separate from ZeroISR in every way, so we need a name for it. We also need a name for us, since we'd be discussing two separate platforms. Name ideas?

I think ZeroHD might be read as 'High Definition', so that's probably not what we want. I suppose we could continue on with the current naming scheme though and use ZeroHDP. I'll work on the clone now, and post it when it's ready.

Here we are. Introducing ZeroHDP - Our new hash database project.

1_1FEikAyxCNPJcW996B69r5UFg29yfq579m.body: You're right. I'm not sure what this is about. It seems to me like this is a problem with zeronet. A possible solution would be to hit the "Download and help distribute all files" switch in the right panel, then go directly into the folder for them.
